Reasoning: The license does not explicitly address the acceptance or rejection of tracking technologies. It focuses on copyright permissions.
The license allows adapting (remix transform and build upon the material) which can include aggregating it with other works provided the other terms (NonCommercial ShareAlike Attribution) are met.
Annotation is a form of adaptation or modification. The license permits adapting the material. Users can add notes or comments.

The license itself does not grant a specific right to anonymize the original licensor or content in a way that would remove attribution requirements. Anonymizing personal data within the material might be subject to other laws but is not a granted permission by this license.
The permission to 'reproduce' and 'share' implies the ability to make copies for archival purposes as long as other license terms are followed.

This action implies the right to assign an attribute to the work. While the license requires attribution TO the original author it does not grant the licensee the right to assign new defining attributes in an ODRL sense.
This is a core component. The license explicitly grants permissions *on the condition* of providing attribution. Thus the ability to use the work while following attribution rules is a permission.
The 'NC' (NonCommercial) part of the license explicitly restricts commercial use. This is a prohibition not a permission.

The license is royalty-free. It does not grant a right for the licensee to receive compensation nor does it require the licensee to compensate the licensor beyond the terms of any separate agreement if one existed. The license itself does not deal with compensation as a granted right.
The license doesn't restrict the number of users who can concurrently use the material assuming they all abide by the license terms. It grants rights to 'You' (the user) generally.
The license grants rights to use and adapt the material not to delete the licensor's original material or to require its deletion. A user can delete their own copies.
The license explicitly allows users to 'Adapt — remix transform and build upon the material' which is the definition of creating derivative works.
This is synonymous with creating derivative works or adapting the material which is permitted.
If the material is in analog form the permission to 'reproduce' and 'adapt' in any 'medium or format' implies the right to digitize it to exercise other permitted rights.
Sharing and reproducing the material implies the right to display it publicly for non-commercial purposes. Section 1.g of the legal code defines 'Share' to include performance and public display.
The license explicitly allows users to 'Share — copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format'.
This is a core permission granted by the license.
The license is non-exclusive. The licensor can grant licenses to others and licensees cannot make their use exclusive.
If the licensed material is software or a script the permission to 'use' and 'adapt' it implies the right to execute it for non-commercial purposes.
Extracting parts of the material is a form of 'reproducing' or 'adapting' which is permitted.
The 'Share' permission allows redistributing the material which includes giving copies to others under the license terms.
The licensee does not have the right to grant use to others in the sense of sublicensing. They can share the work under the original CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 terms. The original licensor grants use.
The permission to 'Adapt — remix transform and build upon the material' implies the right to include the material (or parts of it) in a larger work (an Adaptation) under ShareAlike conditions.
Indexing for non-commercial discovery purposes can be seen as a use or a technical modification necessary to exercise licensed rights. It doesn't conflict with the license.

The license does not grant a specific right to 'inform' in the ODRL sense which usually refers to informing about events or data handling. However a user is permitted to inform others about the work by sharing it.
If the material is software the permission to 'use' it implies the right to install it on a device for non-commercial purposes.
The license permits users to 'Adapt — remix transform and build upon the material' which is modification.
The right to reproduce and use the material implies the ability to move it between storage media or locations as long as other terms are met.
The ShareAlike clause mandates that adaptations are licensed under the same or a compatible license not an arbitrary next policy chosen by the user.
The permission to use the work is conditional on providing notices (copyright license etc.). So the act of using while complying with notice requirements is implicitly a permission.
The license itself is the consent from the licensor. The licensee does not typically 'obtain consent' as a granted ODRL action they operate under the consent already given.
If the material is a media file (audio video) the right to 'Share' (which includes perform) and 'use' implies the right to play it for non-commercial purposes.
This is similar to 'display' or 'play'. Sharing the material includes the right to present it publicly for non-commercial purposes.
The right to 'reproduce' the material in 'any medium or format' includes printing a physical copy for non-commercial use.
The fundamental act of accessing and understanding the content is implied by the permissions to use share and adapt.
The license explicitly grants the right to 'reproduce' the material.
This is a core permission granted by the license.
The license terms are fixed. While a user can review the license (the policy) this is not a granted 'action' in the ODRL sense of having a right to demand a review or change of the policy.
The 'NC' (NonCommercial) part explicitly prohibits selling the material or adaptations.

While primarily an obligation if you create derivative works it's also a permission in the sense that you *are allowed* to create and share those derivative works *if* you comply with the ShareAlike condition.
The license explicitly allows users to 'Share — copy and redistribute the material'.

This specific ODRL action means to make the source code of a policy/license available. The license itself (the policy) is openly available but this action is more about software source code. If the licensed material IS software the license allows sharing it which would include source code if provided but not a specific permission TO the source code of the policy itself via this action.

If the material is suitable for streaming the right to 'Share' (which includes performance and communication to the public) and 'use' in any media or format implies the right to stream it for non-commercial purposes.
Synchronizing media (e.g. audio with video) is a form of adaptation ('remix transform and build upon') which is permitted.
Converting text to speech is a technical modification or an adaptation which is permitted for non-commercial use. It facilitates access and use.
The license explicitly allows users to 'transform' the material as part of the 'Adapt' permission.
Translation is a form of adaptation ('transform') which is permitted. The translated work would be an Adapted Material and subject to ShareAlike.
If the material was installed (e.g. software) the user has the implicit right to uninstall it from their own device. This is a consequence of user control over their own systems.
The entire license is about granting permissions to 'use' the Licensed Material in various ways subject to conditions.

The license does not grant the licensee the right to add a watermark. Adding a watermark could be an 'adaptation' but it might also be seen as a 'technological measure' that restricts others if not done carefully. The license requires not removing existing watermarks if they are part of copyright management information. The act of adding a new one is not an explicitly granted permission.
The license does not prohibit accepting tracking. This is outside the scope of copyright permissions.
Aggregation is permitted under adaptation rights. It is not prohibited.
Annotation is permitted as a form of adaptation. It is not prohibited.

The license does not directly prohibit anonymization. However failing to provide attribution would be a violation. Anonymizing parts of the content for privacy reasons unrelated to attribution is not prohibited by the license itself.
Archiving is not prohibited.
The license doesn't prohibit assigning attributes to the work in a general sense though it doesn't grant this as a right either. Misattribution could be an issue but not 'attribute' itself.
This is an obligation not a prohibition. Failing to provide attribution is a violation but the act of attribution itself is not prohibited.
The 'NC' (NonCommercial) clause explicitly prohibits using the material for commercial purposes. Section 2.a.1.A and B state "for NonCommercial purposes only".
The license does not prohibit offering compensation nor does it prohibit the licensor from seeking it outside of the license terms. The license makes the use royalty-free.
Concurrent use is not prohibited.

Deleting one's own copies is not prohibited. Deleting the original or others' copies without right is generally not allowed but not a specific prohibition of this license beyond normal property rights.
Creating derivative works is permitted.
Deriving new works is permitted.
Digitizing is not prohibited.
Display for non-commercial purposes is permitted. Display for commercial purposes would fall under the commercial use prohibition.
Distribution for non-commercial purposes under the license terms is permitted. Distribution for commercial purposes or without meeting license terms is prohibited.
Distribution itself is permitted. Commercial distribution or distribution not adhering to SA or Attribution is prohibited.
The licensor grants a non-exclusive license. The licensee cannot claim or ensure exclusivity for themselves. Section 2.a.1 grants a "non-exclusive" license.
Execution for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Extraction for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Giving copies (sharing) for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
The licensee may not sublicense the material. They can only share it under the terms of the CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license. Section 2.a.1 grants a "non-sublicensable" license.
Including the work in an adaptation for non-commercial purposes and under ShareAlike is permitted.
Indexing for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
The license does not prohibit informing others about the work.
Installation for non-commercial use is not prohibited.
Modification for non-commercial purposes and under ShareAlike is permitted.
Moving one's own copies is not prohibited.
The ShareAlike condition (Section 3.b) requires that adaptations are licensed under the same terms or a compatible license. Applying a different incompatible 'next policy' is prohibited.
Providing notice is an obligation. Removing or altering required notices is prohibited (Section 3.a.1).
The license does not prohibit seeking additional consents from the licensor for uses beyond the license.
Playing for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Presenting for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Printing for non-commercial use is not prohibited.
Reading the material is not prohibited.
Reproduction for non-commercial purposes and under license terms is permitted.
Reproduction for non-commercial purposes and under license terms is permitted.
The license does not prohibit reviewing the policy.
The 'NC' (NonCommercial) clause explicitly prohibits selling the material or adaptations. This is a form of commercial use.
This is an obligation for adaptations. Failing to ShareAlike adaptations is a violation. The act of ShareAlike itself is not prohibited it's required.
Sharing for non-commercial purposes under license terms is permitted.
The license does not prohibit making source code available. If the licensed work is software and includes source code sharing it would include sharing the source code.
Streaming for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Synchronization as a form of adaptation for non-commercial purposes is not prohibited.
Text-to-speech for non-commercial use is not prohibited.
Transformation for non-commercial purposes under ShareAlike is permitted.
Translation for non-commercial purposes under ShareAlike is permitted.
Uninstalling one's own copy is not prohibited.
Non-commercial use under the license terms is permitted. Commercial use is prohibited.

The license prohibits removing effective technological measures which might include certain types of watermarks (Section 2.a.5.A related to notices and Section 3.a.1). Adding a new watermark is not explicitly prohibited but must not act as an additional restriction on downstream users.
The license does not impose obligations regarding accepting tracking technologies.
While allowed if one aggregates and creates an adaptation then attribution and ShareAlike obligations apply to the new work. The act of aggregation itself is not an obligation.
If annotation creates an adaptation then attribution and ShareAlike obligations apply. The act of annotating is not an obligation.
The license does not require anonymization. It requires attribution.
There is no obligation to archive the material.
This is a core obligation. Section 3.a.1 specifies requirements for attribution to the licensor.
This is a core obligation when sharing or adapting the material. Section 3.a of the legal code details attribution requirements.
This is a prohibition not an obligation. The obligation is to NOT use it commercially.
The license is royalty-free. There is no obligation for the licensee to compensate the licensor under this license.
There are no obligations related to how many users can use it concurrently.
There is no obligation to delete the material.
There is no obligation to create derivative works. If one CHOOSES to create them then other obligations (like ShareAlike) apply.
There is no obligation to derive new works.
There is no obligation to digitize the material.
There is no obligation to display the material.
There is no obligation to distribute the material. If you do distribute then obligations apply.
There is no obligation to distribute. If you do obligations apply.
The license is non-exclusive. There is no obligation for the licensee to ensure exclusivity for anyone.
There is no obligation to execute the material.
There is no obligation to extract parts of the material.
There is no obligation to give the material to others. If you do (share) then obligations apply.
The licensee does not grant use they operate under the grant from the licensor. No obligation here for the licensee.
There is no obligation to include the material in other works. If you do obligations apply.
There is no obligation to index the material.

Section 3.a.1.A.v requires providing a URI/hyperlink to the Licensed Material if supplied. Section 3.a.1.B requires indicating if You modified the Licensed Material. Section 3.a.1.C requires indicating the material is licensed under this license and including its text or URI. These are forms of informing.
There is no obligation to install the material.
There is no obligation to modify the material. If you do obligations apply.
There is no obligation to move the material.

If you create Adapted Material you must license it under the Adapter's License which must be this license a later version or a compatible license (Section 3.b.1). This is an obligation to apply a specific 'next policy'.
Section 3.a requires providing notices: retaining identification copyright notices license notices disclaimer notices and indicating modifications.
The license doesn't obligate the licensee to obtain further consent for licensed uses. For uses outside the license consent would be needed but that's not an obligation OF the license.
There is no obligation to play the material.
There is no obligation to present the material.
There is no obligation to print the material.
There is no obligation to read the material.
There is no obligation to reproduce the material. If you do then obligations apply.
There is no obligation to reproduce. If you do then obligations apply.
There is no obligation for the licensee to review the policy though it is advisable.
Selling is prohibited.
If you produce Share or Reproduce Adapted Material you must license it under the same or compatible terms. Section 3.b details the ShareAlike obligations.
There is no obligation to share. If you do share then obligations (Attribution NonCommercial ShareAlike for adaptations) apply.

The license does not generally obligate providing source code unless the licensed material is software and providing source code is the established norm for sharing that type of software under an open license and is necessary to exercise the rights. This specific ODRL action is about the policy's source.
There is no obligation to stream the material.
There is no obligation to synchronize material.
There is no obligation to create a text-to-speech version.
There is no obligation to transform the material. If you do obligations apply.
There is no obligation to translate the material. If you do (creating an adaptation) then ShareAlike and Attribution obligations apply.
There is no obligation to uninstall the material.
There is no obligation to use the material.
There is no obligation to add a watermark. There is an obligation not to remove existing copyright management information which might include watermarks (Section 3.a.1).
